definition: Cheng Miao, a jailer-turned-prisoner in the Qin dynasty who created the clerical style of Chinese calligraphy
surname Cheng
rule/order/regulations/formula/journey/procedure/sequence
profound/remote
Li Si (c. 280-208 BC), Legalist philosopher, calligrapher and prime minister of Qin kingdom and Qin dynasty from 246 to 208 BC
prison guard/jailer (old)
the great seal/used narrowly for 籀文/used broadly for many pre-Qin scripts
seal script as unified by the Qin dynasty/the small seal 小篆 and great seal 大篆

minor government official or functionary (old)
early form of Chinese characters inscribed in stone, a precursor of the small seal 小篆[xiao3 zhuan4]

seal script used throughout the pre-Han period
writing up of official or judicial documents/pettifoggery
Xiping steles, calligraphic work on carved steles of the Eastern Han Dynasty (25-220 AD)

Qin dynasty (221-207 BC), founded by the first emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], the first dynasty to rule the whole of China

Wei Lao (c. 450 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), advisor to the first Qin emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], possible author of the Wei Liaozi 尉繚子|尉缭子[Wei4 Liao2 zi5] text on military strategy
